ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: The nutritional benefits of breast milk last only until the baby is weaned from breast milk.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Formula-feeding is more convenient than breast-feeding.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Breast-feeding increases mother-infant bonding.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Break milk is lacking in iron.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Formula-fed babies are more likely to be overfed than are breast-fed babies.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Formula-feeding is the better choice if a mother plans to work outside the home.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Mothers who formula-feed miss one of the great joys of motherhood.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Women should not breast-feed in public places such as restaurants.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Babies fed breast milk are healthier than babies who are fed formula.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Breast-fed babies are more likely to be overfed than formula-fed babies.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Fathers feel left out if a mother breast-feeds.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Breast milk is the ideal food for babies.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Breast milk is more easily digested than formula.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Formula is as healthy for an infant as breast milk.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Breast-feeding is more convenient than formula feeding.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: Breast milk is less expensive than formula.
Notes: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly agree

ElementDescription: A mother who occasionally drinks alcohol should not breast-feed her baby.
Notes: 1 = Strongly agree; 2 = Agree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Disagree; 5 = Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Iowa Infant Feeding Attitude Scale Total Score
Notes: Sum of responses to iifas_1 through iifas_17. Higher scores indicate more positive attitudes toward breast-feeding.
